data.text: Contents
Introduction

This document is specifically for the Research laboratory at Broomfield site and outlines the correct guidelines for handling bodily fluids, dry ice and using laboratory equipment. It is essential to minimise the risk of injury and infection to EVERYONE coming into contact with the specimens and equipment, while also maintaining the quality of the specimens.
Scope
The purpose of this document is:
To describe safe practice which must be followed by all staff involved in specimen preparation, storage and shipment.

Be used alongside each trials research lab manual, identifying which samples are required to be taken and the individual conditions required to stabilise the specimen before and how to ship the specimens to a central lab for analysis.
Definitions

table_items.text: RPM: ‘Revolutions Per Minute' is the number of revolutions of the centrifuge arm completed each minute

Relative Centrifugal Force (RCF) (the same as G force essentially). This is the amount of speed applied to a sample in order to separate it into plasma and cellular products. The following equation can be used to work out G force or RCF 1.12 x Radius of rotation (mm) x (RPM/1000)².
The distance from the centre of rotation to the position in the centrifuge tube of the material being spun (the base of the bucket when fully swung out) is the radius of rotation.

data.text: Role and responsibilities within the Trust
Pathology Quality and Governance Group to ensure the correct Governance is in place.
Lead Research Nurse to ensure that staff are aware of SOP and follow the guidance of this document.
Procedure

This SOP describes the role of research staff preparing specimens for analysis covering the topics of health and safety within the laboratory while preforming procedures, as all human and animal products must be handled as potentially hazardous.
5.1.1 Protective clothing
All members of staff must wear appropriate protective clothing provided by the Trust when working in the laboratory.
Protective clothing must be properly fastened at all times.
Ensure arms are fully covered when using the -80⁰C Freezers and Handling Dry Ice.

If you think that your protective clothing has been contaminated, you must change into fresh protective clothing immediately and place the garment into the soluble wash bags provided by and given to the laundry for decontamination.
A laboratory coat must be worn when within the laboratory environment.
Staff must leave their protective clothing in the laboratory before leaving or visiting any non-laboratory site, i.e. wards, canteen, library, etc. Coats must be left on the pegs provided.
Protective clothing must not be placed with outside clothing, nor allowed to brush against non-protected staff.
Wear fresh protective clothing when visiting any ward, theatre or clinical department if appropriate.
Sufficient garments should always be available for use by visitors and must be worn during their visit to the laboratory.
5.1.2 Footwear
Should be appropriate for the working environment. Footwear should cover the front of the feet and be made of non-absorbent material.
5.1.3 Hair

Long hair (including long beards and moustaches) should be tied back or contained, when involved in clinical work or in handling machinery to prevent the spread of infection or trauma as a result of hair being caught in machinery.
5.1.4 Gloves
Disposable gloves must be worn when handling all specimen samples and when cleaning any laboratory surfaces and apparatus.
For the safe removal of disposable gloves, follow the below guidelines:

Wear Suitable Thermal (BS EN 511) gloves for -80⁰C Freezers and Handling Dry Ice. – regularly check the gloves for signs of compromise such as split seams etc. and report any defective items to your line manager.
5.1.5 Eyes
Wear Suitable eye protection (glasses or spectacles are not sufficient) when Handling Dry Ice and defrosting the -80⁰C Freezers.
5.1.6 Hand washing
All staff must frequently wash their hands during work periods and always before leaving a work area.
Hands must be washed after removing protective clothing and after removing gloves.
All staff must attend a bi-yearly Hand Hygiene Infection Control Update course.
5.1.7 Food and drink / smoking/ cosmetics
Food and drink must not be eaten, drunk, taken into or stored in any laboratory room fridge or freezer. Food and drink must only be stored in designated staff rest areas and refrigerators.
Smoking and vaping is banned in all Trust buildings, grounds and vehicles. There are no designated smoking or vaping areas.
Cosmetics, other than hand cream after washing, must not be applied in any laboratory or place where specimens are handled.
Envelopes must not be licked to seal them.
5.1.8 Cuts and grazes
All cuts and grazes on exposed areas of the body must be covered with a waterproof dressing.
Any cuts/grazes obtained through working practices must be reported to your line manager and onto the trust incident system (Datix).
5.1.9 Visitors
Only authorised personnel may have entry to the laboratory.

Maintenance staff and service engineers must be offered protective clothing, advised to wash their hands and be supervised during their visits. They must not be allowed access to any potentially infected apparatus until it has been correctly decontaminated.
Handling bodily fluids
Gloves and a lab coat/apron must be worn at ALL times when handling ALL specimens.
Do not leave clinical area whilst still wearing gloves. Remove gloves, wash your hands and replace with new gloves when you return.
Do not overfill the sharps bin. If it is full (up to the fill line), seal the lid securely, sign and date the bin. Then place in the appropriate clinical waste collection area.
All tubes/aliquots must be clearly labelled with indelible pen or with the labels provided by the trial and fully completed prior to storing in the freezer.
Contaminated materials such as used pipettes, blood bottles, gloves, etc. are to be put into orange clinical waste bins.
All waste (except reagents) will need be taken to the waste collection area.
Waste Reagents are to be disposed of according to their individual Safety Data Sheet. – A hard copy for each reagent can be found on EDGE and in the ‘Reagent' Folder.
5.2.1  Spillages of bodily fluids
Blood and body fluid spillages can be unpredictable and can happen at any time.
All spillages of blood or body fluid are potentially infectious.
The person witnessing or discovering the event MUST deal with the spillage immediately.
When a spillage occurs you need to do an assessment of:
Then based on this assessment take the appropriate action to clean the spillage effectively.
If you are in any doubt as to what to do, or the spillage is:
Immediately report the spillage to a senior research nurse who will advise what action to take, as a Spill Pak or a Biohazard Spill Kit may be required.

Personal protective equipment such as disposable gloves, apron and eye protection must be worn to prevent skin and eye exposure, or contamination of clothing. Face protection may be needed if it is suspected there will be splashes to the eyes or mouth.
Carefully remove any broken containers (with tweezers if necessary) and place the pieces into a sharps bin.
Use a High Level Medical Surface Disinfectant such as ChemGene HLD H to
encircle the spill and paper towels to clear the spill (from the outside in), placing
the contaminated towels into an orange clinical waste bin, as you go along.
Change your gloves and any other contaminated personal protective equipment.

Cover the area where the spill occurred (including any ‘splash zones') with disinfectant, leave for a few minutes then clear up with paper towels, placing the contaminated towels into an orange clinical waste bin, as you go along.
Change your gloves and any other contaminated personal protective equipment. Wash your hands and continue with your day.
Spillages that are a Near Miss Incident, release of dangerous substance or have been as a result of equipment issues, slips/trips/falls must be reported on the
trust incident system (Datix).
Method for obtaining histology samples
Research Nurse supplies the patient consent form and identifies the sample and sample type (Slides/Tumour Block) required to be sent away, as per the trial protocol.

The Research Assistant checks where the required sample is currently located, whether that is locally (Broomfield Hospital Histopathology) via searching on MEHT Review or located at another histology laboratory.

If the specimen is located at another histology laboratory, it may be necessary to obtain which location the specimen has been obtained from, using the information on the report contained in the patients' medical notes.
Obtain a copy of the report for the respective sample(s), which will contain a laboratory reference number.
Then the relevant laboratory will need to be contacted and provided with a copy of the patients consent form, in order to request the sample.
Locally held specimens
The subject of the email will state the required sample type and research trial.
The relevant Trial name and lab number and the specimen type required must be stated in the main email.
The patient details (Full name, DOB, Hospital Number and NHS Number) will be attached in a separate document.
A copy of the patients consent form will also be attached.
Specimens from other laboratories
The subject of the email will state the required sample type and research trial.
The relevant Trial name and lab number and the specimen required.
The patient details (Full name, DOB, Hospital Number and NHS Number) will be attached in a separate document (if sent as an email).

Include the address of where you would like the specimen(s) to be sent out to. This is usually the Research office – in order to complete the relevant CRF's and anonymise the sample and report before shipment.
Also ensure the Research Assistants and or Research Nurses' contact information is clearly stated in the communication in case of any queries arising from the laboratory.
The specimen will then be sent out typically in the post to the Research Assistant
Once the specimen has been obtained
The Specimen(s) are ALL anonymised, with only the relevant Trial Name, Trial ID number/code, DOB.
The Report is anonymised with only the relevant Trial Name, Trial ID number/code, DOB, and number of slides and or Block Identifying Number(s) (found on each tumour block).
Possibly a CRF form for the relevant trial and time point.
And a return address for the specimens to be returned to once their analysis is complete.
Method for histological specimen processing and storage.
Reagents
Reagents will have their Safety Data Sheet reviewed before being allowed on site to primarily assess their storage, safety and disposal requirements to ensure they can be dealt with appropriately.
Each individual Data Sheet will be stored on the EDGE Database and a hard copy in the Reagent folder in the lab for quick reference if needed.
Centrifuging
Individual Trial Lab Manuals will identify which samples and tests require centrifugation and at what velocity, time and if appropriate temperature this should be at.
8.1.1 It is the responsibility of staff members using the equipment to ensure that it is used appropriately, safely and according to this procedure and the manufacturer's instructions.
8.1.2 The centrifuges identified in this procedure may be used by Research staff trained in their use.

8.1.3 Where problems and faults occur, staff are responsible for reporting these to a Senior Research Nurse, who will advise on the appropriate action to take and ensure assistance is available if required (where breakages and spillages occur).
Breakages
Any breakages/spillages within the centrifuge should be immediately reported to a Senior Research Nurse who will advise what action to take.

8.2.1  If the user is aware that a breakage has occurred within the centrifuge during use, (by a noise etc.), where possible do not open the lid (as some of the sample may have become aerosolised) and leave for  minutes prior to opening. If the lid has been removed, replace it as soon as possible. Then;
iii Any broken glass or plastic from the blood/sample bottles to be handled with
extreme care and placed into sharps bin. Discard bucket contents down the sluice/toilet and flush twice. Clean the rotor/bucket with detergent, dry and replace into centrifuge
Calibration and maintenance
The Research Assistant is responsible for ensuring the equipment is calibrated annually and serviced twice annually by a United Kingdom Accreditation Service (UKAS) supplier to ISO/IEC 17025.

Centrifuges are serviced at six monthly intervals and calibrated annually unless repair requires calibration to be performed before the device is used. They are calibrated for time, and velocity. Where centrifuges may be refrigerated they are also calibrated for temperature.
Contact details of current UKAS accredited supplier: Research and Medical Services Limited (RMS Ltd)
34 Green Lane
Burnham Slough SL1 8DX
Primary Contact:
RMS Ltd
Tel: 07733 120165 (Mobile) E-Mail: pcoogan@btconnect.com
Login details for service and calibration certificates:
www.rmslabcare.co.uk Username: S251 Password: CM15ETrms
Dashboard – Completed Calls – S405 Broomfield Hospital Research Lab – Select Date Range – Search – Select Call Number – Download Job Sheet

Check that the Calibration Certificate no longer has a DRAFT watermark; this can take up to a month. Then save a copy on to the EDGE database and print a copy to store in the Lab Equipment Records Folder.
Centrifuges used by the research department

table_items.text: Date of First Use By Research Department

data.text: Routine operation of centrifuges
Please use the instructions below in conjunction with the appropriate user manual. Checklist
If load is unbalanced and machine starts to shake, switch off immediately and clear the area until the machine stops.
NEVER try to open the centrifuge while the rotor is spinning.
Do not use a centrifuge if:-
8.5.1 Eppendorf 5804 R
a) Balance pairs of samples and adapters. (Water balance tubes are available if blood samples do not pair adequately).
b) Then place them opposite each other in centrifuge buckets. All four buckets must be present in the centrifuge before proceeding, even if some are empty.
c) When all samples have been balanced and loaded ensure all buckets can swing out freely. Then close and hold the lid down until it automatically locks in position.

d) Set the desired speed, time and temperature. By pressing the button for the parameter that needs adjusting these are directly under those on the display. The selected parameter will then flash on the display and then press the ^ and ˅ buttons repeatedly until the desired setting is reached.
(Full brake/acceleration = 9, No brake/acceleration = 0)
e) Once the desired parameters have been selected, Press start and wait by the machine until it reaches and settles at the selected speed.
f) When the appropriate spin time is finished and the rotor has stopped the centrifuge will beep.
g) Press the Open button and the lid will automatically open for you to unload the samples.
8.5.2 Eppendorf 5418 R
a) Balance pairs of samples and adapters. (Water balance tubes are available if blood samples do not pair adequately).
b) Then place them opposite each other in the rotor.
c) When all samples have been balanced and loaded, secure the internal lid by holding the rotor still and twisting the red nut clockwise until it clicks into position.
d) Once this is secure, close and hold the lid down until it automatically locks in position.
e) Set the desired speed, time and temperature.
i.  Press the speed dial in to switch from RPM to RCF (g) (rpm or rcf will be displayed on the screen). Turn the same dial to adjust the speed. The displayed speed is x1000, so 6.5 = 6500rpm.
f) Once the desired parameters have been selected, Press start (by pushing in the time dial) and wait by the machine until it reaches and settles at the selected speed.
g) When the appropriate spin time has finished and the rotor has stopped the centrifuge will beep.
h) Press the Open button and the lid will automatically open for you to unload the samples.
Limitations
Failure to observe the proper operating instructions could result in damage to the machine in use, the sample involved or even to the operator themselves.

If the process is interrupted (for example due to power failure or centrifuge imbalance) where patient samples are being centrifuged ready for separation of the plasma, the process should be repeated in full.
Air displacement pipetting.
8.7.1 Research micropipette – Acura 825 Socorex Serial No 14111846 (100ul–1000ul) (autoclavable)
8.7.2 Background
They work a little like a syringe, except there is an air filled cushion between the piston and the sample.
The volume of the air cushion is affected by temperature and pressure and some volatile solvents can evaporate into it. Each of these can affect pipetting accuracy.
The accuracy of micro-pipettes depends on the user. They will need to practice good technique and have an understanding of how the pipette works and they must also be well maintained.

There are two stages on the piston of the pipette. It is critical these are used correctly. The piston should be pushed down to the aspirate position (the first stage) before drawing up the solution, and then push down to the purge position (second stage) for decanting.
The volume adjustment dial near the top of the micropipette allows adjustment to the volume that is measured.
Use well-fitting tips. Poorly fitting tips allow air to escape when drawing up and dispensing, leading to inaccurate amounts.
8.7.3 Good technique
Use a sensible pipette for the volume you want to dispense. The research micropipette measures 100ul-1000ul.
The accuracy of your pipette decreases as the dispensed volume approaches the minimum and maximum that the pipette can handle.
The most important rules to follow are:
Pipette with a slow smooth action. You should not see any bubbles.
Hold the pipette vertically when drawing up liquid, keeping the tip at a constant depth below the surface of the liquid.
Only immerse the tip slightly when drawing up liquid – otherwise you will coat the outside of the tip with liquid, which will be transferred with the volume inside the pipette.
When dispensing the liquid, hold the pipette vertically but keep the sidewall of the receiving vessel at a  degree angle. Pipette against the side wall or into the liquid that's already there.
Pre-wet the pipette tip by drawing up the liquid into your pipette then dispense back into the original vessel.
Change the tip before aspirating a different liquid or sample.
Change the tip if a droplet remains at the end of the tip from the previous pipetting operation.
Liquid should never enter the tip holder; to prevent this, when there is liquid inside the tip.
NEVER turn the pipette upside down.
NEVER lay the pipette on its side.
ALWAYS keep the top (push-button) of the pipette higher than the tip holder e.g. rest it against a rack, both in storage and in use.
8.7.4 General procedure for pipetting
8.7.5 Maintenance
If the research micropipette becomes contaminated with bio-hazardous material it can be autoclaved, there is an autoclave in Microbiology that can be used for this.

Store the pipette vertically, using a pipette holder. This prevents any liquids that have sneaked into the barrel of the pipette from getting any further inside and causing possible corrosion / damage.
8.7.6 Performing pipette checks
A pipette check should be carried out every month. (When the pipette is in active use)
Where 2 different volumes of water are measured out 10 times on to a high sensitivity scale and the readings noted down (100ul = 0.1g on high precision scales).
These readings are then added on to a spread sheet which calculates the range, mean (must be within 5%), standard deviation (SD) and Coefficient of Variation (CV) (must be less than 5).
The spread sheet will then be updated every month, while the pipette is in active use) and added to the EDGE database.
Dry ice
Properties
Solid Carbon dioxide (supplied as pellets, slices or blocks)
Extremely cold (-78C)
Nonflammable, gas is colourless, odourless (except at very high concentrations)
Asphyxiant – normal concentration in air 0.035% (>0.5% can be dangerous)
It Sublimes – turns from solid into gas, it does not ‘melt into liquid'
Gas form is heavier than air – (will fill an area or room from the ground up)
Small volume of solid produces a very large volume of gas (10kg = 5.4m3 gas) – NEVER to be taken in a lift if not securely packaged.
Hazards
Contact with product may cause cold burns or frostbite (brief contact causes little harm – prolonged contact freezes cells)
In low concentrations may cause increased respiration and headache.
In high concentrations sublimed vapour may cause asphyxiation.
Transport
Risk of unsafe atmosphere due to sublimation.
Spillages – largest form is safest (i.e. pellets are the highest risk, then slices, then blocks).
Loads must be secured and isolated wherever possible.

Do not transport in the passenger compartment of a car or in the cab of a lorry. If absolutely necessary ensure adequate ventilation for the size of load and ALWAYS ensure FRESH air is drawn into the vehicle from outside.
Consider the quantity of dry ice, the time transportation will take and the temperature of the compartment.
NEVER put dry ice inside a sealed container (pressurisation - explosion).
Use a polystyrene box with a loose fitting lid.
Use and handling
DO NOT handle dry ice with bare hands – use suitable (thermal) gloves.
ALWAYS use eye protection.
DO NOT add water – this increases sublimation.
DO NOT place in a refrigerator or freezer.
DO NOT allow gas to accumulate.
DO NOT put it in a sink.
Dry ice is used for freezing or cooling:
If freezing, place above the item to be frozen.
For cooling, place dry ice in the bottom of the container, cover with a layer of insulating material, then place the item to cool on the top.
Do not allow direct contact between the specimens and the dry ice or items may suffer freezer burn, (use the insulating pouches – normally supplied with the dry ice).
Storage
Dry Ice is NOT stored at the trust
If it ever needs to be stored the area has to be:
If well insulated containers are used the dry ice will remain solid for longer.
Disposal
If a small amount (up to 5kg) of dry ice needs to be disposed of, place the dry ice in a closed insulated box and leave the box in a secure well ventilated area.
ALWAYS ensure dry ice is left to sublime in a safe, secure and well ventilated place.
NEVER dispose of in sinks and toilets as it may damage pipes and other parts and cause a sudden concentration of CO .
First aid – dry ice, cold burn and frostbite
Eye contact – Flush immediately with water – for at least 15 minutes.
Skin contact – If Frostbite / Cold burn have occurred – spray with tepid water for at least  minutes, apply a sterile dressing, and seek medical assistance.
Inhalation
Asphyxiation may not be apparent to casualty – symptoms include headache, loss of mobility / consciousness, possibly resulting in death.
Remove casualty to uncontaminated area (using self-contained breathing apparatus).
Keep casualty warm and rested, call for medical assistance (resuscitate if necessary).
Specimen transportation

In order to reduce the inherent risks to shippers, carriers and the general public as well as eliminating the risk of incurring liabilities. The following basic principles must be followed by all laboratory staff when sending any diagnostic specimens or any other infectious substance(s) either within the UK, or internationally.

International regulations for the transport of diagnostic specimens and infectious substances, by any mode of transport, are based on the Recommendations of the United Nations (UN) Committee of Experts on the Transport of Dangerous Goods (UNETDG). The Universal Postal Union reflects these recommendations in its regulations, particularly for packaging, whilst the International Civil Aviation Organisation (ICAO) and the International Air Transport Association (IATA) have also incorporated the UN recommendations in their regulations, as have other international transport organisations. The World Health Organisation (WHO) serves in an advisory capacity to these bodies. Currently the IATA has the most stringent conditions for shipment and transportation of infectious substances and much of this document is based on this standard, the Infectious Substances Shipping Guidelines (ISSG). ADR, The Agreement concerning the International Carriage of Dangerous Goods by Road, 2021 is the regulation that applies solely to road carriage of dangerous goods. It is implemented into UK regulation via The Carriage of Dangerous Goods and Use of Transportable Pressure Equipment Regulations 2009, as amended.
The IATA training course for the shipment of these Dangerous Goods can be found at  https://news.mayocliniclabs.com/2019/06/26/dangerous-goods-training/
This training requires renewing every 2 years.
Further information on specimen transport legislation can be found on the EDGE database and can be sourced from the trusts Dangerous Goods Safety Advisor
All biological substances are defined as either Category A or B:
Category A – Infectious substance (Pathogens) UN 2814 (Human) / UN2900 (animal) “Infectious Substance, Affecting Humans” / “Infectious Substance, Affecting Animals only”.

An infectious substance which is carried in a form that, when exposure to it occurs is capable of causing permanent disability, life threatening or fatal disease in otherwise healthy humans or animals.
Category B – Pathogens UN3373 “Biological Substance, Category B”.
An infectious substance which does not meet the criteria for inclusion in Category A.
The vast majority of diagnostic specimens sent for research trials fall into Category B.
Packaging – UN3373 Biological Substance, Category B

ALL biological substances meeting the classification of UN3373 MUST be packed to P650 Packaging Instructions for transportation. The following summary details information for road carriage (ADR) with any additional requirements for air carriage (IATA) highlighted in the text.
Category B – UN3373 – P650 Summary
3 layers of packaging.
Capable of successfully passing a 1.2 m drop test.
Primary and secondary receptacles water tight and capable of withstanding, without leakage, an internal pressure of 95 kPa (0.95 bar).
Primary receptacle wrapped in absorbent material sufficient to absorb the entire contents of the primary receptacle(s).
Secondary receptacle may hold several primary receptacles.
Secondary or Outer packaging shall be rigid- road carriage.
Outer packaging shall be rigid – air carriage.
N.B: Where packages are sent to clients using The Royal Mail, IATA compliant packaging must be used.
Packaging for each trial will vary from study to study. Follow the instructions as stated in the individual lab manual for a trial.
These will ALL fundamentally require a minimum oflayers of packaging:

Primary receptacles shall be packed in secondary packaging in such a way that, under normal conditions of carriage, they cannot break, be punctured or leak their contents into the secondary packaging.
Secondary packaging shall be secured in outer packaging with suitable cushioning material.
Any leakage of the contents shall not compromise the integrity of the cushioning material or of the outer packaging.
If sending by air an itemized list of contents shall be enclosed between the secondary packaging and outer packaging” – IATA.
The outer packaging used for UN3373 patient specimens must be marked as follows (adjacent to each other):
“Biological Substance, Category B” at least 6 mm high;
“UN3373” at least 6 mm high inside a diamond-shaped mark. The minimum dimensions of the diamond-shaped mark are 50 mm x  mm with the width of the line forming the diamond at least 2 mm.
Dry Ice (road carriage)
When dry ice (solid carbon dioxide) or ice is used as a coolant/conditioner to keep specimens cold, the following requirements must be met:
If ice is used, the outside packaging or overpack must be leakproof.
The ice or dry ice must be placed outside the secondary packagings or in the outer packaging or an overpack.
Interior supports must be provided to secure the secondary packagings in the original position after the ice or dry ice has dissipated.
If dry ice is used, the packaging must be designed and constructed to permit the release of carbon dioxide gas to prevent a build-up of pressure that could rupture the packagings.

The primary receptacle and the secondary packaging must maintain their integrity at the temperature of the refrigerant used as well as the temperatures and the pressures which could result if refrigeration were lost.
Packages containing dry ice for cooling shall be marked with the following wording:
The markings shall be durable, legible and placed in such a location and of such a size relative to the package as to be readily visible.
Packaging Instruction 954 – Dry Ice (air carriage)
If dry ice is used packaging instruction  must also be applied.
The packaging must be designed and constructed to permit the release of carbon dioxide gas to prevent the possibility of a build-up of pressure that could rupture the packaging.
Usually the dry ice is contained in a  compliant ‘overpack'. If an overpack is used all marking and labeling must be repeated on the overpack.
Total net weight of dry ice inside the overpack; and
“OVERPACK”  mm high letters.
Marks and labels required on outer packaging for air carriage:
“Carbon Dioxide, Solid” or “Dry Ice”;
Full name and address of the shipper and consignee
Name and telephone number of a responsible person;
Net weight of dry ice; and
Class 9 Miscellaneous Dangerous Goods Label.
Transport documentation
If sending a compliant UN3373 package by road (including with dry ice), no transport documentation is required to accompany the package.
If sending a compliant UN3373 package by air, an air waybill is required. The “nature and quantity of goods” box requires the following information:
“Biological Substance, Category B”
Number of packages
If sending a compliant UN3373 package by air on dry ice, the following is required in the “nature and quantity of goods” box – in addition to that above:
“Dry Ice” or “Carbon Dioxide, solid”;
Number of packages; and
The net weight of dry ice in each package.
Fridge and freezers

table_items.text: Date of First Use By Research Department

data.text: The manuals for the research owned fridge and -80°C freezer can be found on the EDGE database, as well as in the instruction manuals folder. The Microbiology owned -80°C Covid freezer manual is stored within the Microbiology Department.

Personal protective equipment will be worn when accessing the -80⁰C freezers. Ensuring that arms are fully covered, are wearing suitable thermal (BS EN 511) gloves and suitable eye protection when defrosting.
Every month any excess ice formed in the -80°C freezer is scraped away using the lab ice scraper.
-80⁰C Microbiology Covid Freezer   -80⁰C Freezer Generic   +4⁰C Fridge
Laboratory temperature logs
Can be accessed through www.kelsius.com
The generic log on for the labs temperature records:-
Microbiology Records Username: research Password: Temperatures753
Microbiology  (Backup/Generic) Microbiology CovidFrz

The Laboratory Research ⁰C Freezer is not temperature monitored as it only contains ice packs and the Research +4⁰C Fridge temperatures are recorded each day on paper by the research laboratory assistant.
For those on the Kelsius website:
Once logged in:
Click on Sensor Graphs – Temperature Sensors
Input ‘Quick Date Range' and ‘Last Month' or whatever ‘Exact Date Range' is required
Select the required sensor from the drop down list
Click on Display chart (wait)
Click on Download detailed records PDF Icon
Save the record in your documents.
Print the first 2 pages of each report and file in the ‘Lab Equipment Records' folder.
Repeat for each sensor.
Then upload all the PDF records on to the EDGE database.

Centrifuge service (6 months) and calibration (yearly)
Fridge and Freezer temperature records (monthly)
Pipette Check Results (monthly) – Recorded when necessary
Lab Accreditation Documents (yearly)
Lab Head CV's (every 2 years)
Reference Ranges – signed by the lead clinician (every year)
Current Transport Legislation
P650 Packing Instructions
Training requirements
All staff that work within the Research laboratory require: -80⁰C freezer training required
Pipette training
Centrifuge training
Dangerous Goods Safety Awareness provided by the DGSA
Monitoring and audit
Outlined below is the Trust's process of monitoring compliance with, and the effectiveness of the document's main points.

table_items.text: Aspect of compliance or effectiveness being monitored
Individual department responsible for the monitoring
Group / Committee / forum which will receive the findings/monitoring report
Committee / individual responsible for ensuring the actions are completed
Duties relating to repair and maintenance

data.text: Approval and implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by the Quality Management group for Pathology which is the specialist group with the authority to approve local laboratory guidelines. These will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform the Research and Development Committee and Research Staff of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
Equality impact assessment
The Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals. (Refer to appendix 2)
References
Human Tissue Authority (2017) Code of Practice A: Guiding principles and the fundamental principles of consent. Online at Code A (hta.gov.uk) [Accessed 6.12.2021]

British Standards Institute (2014) Medical Laboratories: requirements for quality and competence. (ISO 15189: 2012). Online at ISO - ISO 15189:2012 - Medical laboratories — Requirements for quality and competence [Accessed 6.12.2021]
UK Government Publication (updated 2021) Good clinical practice for clinical trials. Online at https://www.gov.uk/guidance/good-clinical-practice-for-clinical-trials [Accessed 6.12.2021]

☒ A change to an existing document
☒ A change to the way staff work
What are you proposing to change?
The SOP needed updating as the premises has moved to a new location embedded in the Research Centre
Why are you making this change? (What will the change achieve?)
Some of the equipment has changed since the previous SOP
Who benefits from this change and how?
Staff are aware of the changes of the laboratory premises
Is anyone likely to suffer any negative impact as a result of this change? If no, please record reasons here and sign and date this assessment. If yes, please complete a full EIA.
a) Will you be undertaking any consultation as part of this change?
Yes Quality Manager of Pathology and Health and Safety
